[h1] Death Stranding might be the most cooperative game you'll ever play alone. [/h1]

A game everyone should try even though its not for everyone.


[h3] Gameplay [/h3]
Death Stranding is one of the most uniquely cooperative games I‚Äôve ever played, even without traditional multiplayer. From the moment you take your first steps, you realize it‚Äôs about more than just getting from point A to point B. You start to understand that Death Stranding isn‚Äôt testing your reflexes but your patience, your planning, and your willingness to keep on keeping on.

After getting your bearings, you‚Äôll begin to implement tools to create more efficient routes using ladders, ropes, and structures. Combat in this game is limited, but that‚Äôs kind of the point given the story‚Äôs context. Along your mission to reconnect America through the Chiral Network, you‚Äôll come across lost cargo, abandoned vehicles, structures, and motivational signs left by other online players in this asynchronous multiplayer world. It‚Äôs a type of multiplayer experience unlike anything I‚Äôve played before, and it fits Death Stranding‚Äôs themes perfectly.

To keep things simple (since this borders on spoiler territory): you‚Äôll have a companion, BB, who starts off as more of a tool for detecting BTs (Beached Things). They appear as muck-like monsters ([spoiler] but are actually spirits [/spoiler]).. You can choose to confront or evade BTs; I usually prefer the latter. The roughest patches in the gameplay, for me, were the driving sections and the occasional climbing mishap; for example a jump would trigger accidentally, causing you to drop cargo or injure yourself.


[h3] Story [/h3]

When this game came out in November 2019, it was not well received by many critics and fans of Kojima's previous games. Why should anyone care about delivering packages in a world where most NPCs are locked inside their homes and remain socially distant via hologram? 

Well one pandemic later and Death Stranding became more than just some dumb walking simulator.

The story isn‚Äôt perfect, but it contains some of the most fascinating world-building I‚Äôve experienced in any medium. In the world of Death Stranding, an extinction-level event has reshaped the world. The United States and its people are fractured. As mentioned before, your mission as Sam Porter Bridges is to reconnect America with the Chiral Network and in your time delivering packages you'll unfold a terrorist plot, scientific milestones and deal with Sam's aphenphosmphobia (Fear of being touched). 

The storytelling can be exhausting at times due to its heavy exposition and repetitive dialogue. There were moments when I couldn‚Äôt tell if the awkwardness came from the writing or the acting choices; however the performances are strong, especially given the stacked cast featuring Norman Reedus, L√©a Seydoux, Margaret Qualley, Mads Mikkelsen, and more.

[h3] Rating [/h3]

Few games capture the feeling of loneliness and hope in the same breath the way Death Stranding does. Its haunting visuals and music by Low Roar turn even the simplest deliveries into reflective, emotional moments. It‚Äôs an engaging yet deceptively simple game with an emotionally rich story about reconnection and perseverance through isolation. The act of delivering packages becomes more meaningful through the relationships you build and the quiet victories that come from bridging the gaps between people and places. The COVID-19 pandemic changed how I see this game; what once felt like a strange concept now feels deeply human. I‚Äôd give Death Stranding a 4/5.

Fantastically unique experience with a world built on creating moments that define the journey instead of the destination. It is both strategic and cumbersome in how it juggles a theraputic navigation between multiple points and delivering its story beats.

You approach the game's plot in a method less akin to Hideo's previous games where the backstories and nuances of each character's motives are made reasonably clear, instead, opting for text based emails and interviews which most players are most likely not interacting with considering only a mere 7.2% of players have read 100 interviews and 19.3% for 100 emails read (time of this review). I've seen players say that you should be able to listen to an audio clip of interviews/ emails while doing deliveries but I believe that would detract from the main gameplay loop. The trips you make allow the player to narrow in on the each moment or use the time to reflect on their current place in the story and understand, wonder, and imagine what is next for Sam and his allies/ enemies. It was purposefully done and it may have sacrificed on overall cohesiveness with how to deliver more of the lore for an America torn apart.

Assymetric Gameplay also manages to sublty sew in astrange feeling of being alone but not ignored as other players in multiple ways.

If you do enjoy reflecting on your ties in your life or have dealt with death in some regard, this may be an interesting game to wade through and reflect on both. It has goofy game moments, a certain clunkiness that gives movement its weight, charm from the characters you meet and pure out of the box ideas in terms of science fiction.

I would recommend this game to everyone, though I know not everyone would do the same.

[u]Without spoiling anything:[/u] It starts out as a story about humanity's twisted priorities, in which the world is plagued with unimaginable human suffering and grief, but we've collectively decided Amazon Prime is more important, so get delivering those packages buddy. Everything seems pointless, you are given pittance as reward, and sometimes it almost feels like it's mocking you for persevering. I was already hooked by that initial premise alone, along with the incredible horror in its presentation, but as the game progresses it becomes a profound and captivating story about connecting with people, and the lengths to which humans will go to make those connections in spite of the suffering we endure. 

But what makes this game so compelling is the fact this story simply cannot be told in any other medium than a video game. You [i]need[/i] to rely on the assistance of other players. You will quickly learn to appreciate their assistance and you will feel compelled to help other players in return. A single player game in which you are routinely thinking about how you can either help other players or just try to make them smile. It simply [i]is not[/i] just an interactive movie, it's so much more than that! It is beautiful, tragic, heartwarming, terrifying, and unlike anything I have ever experienced in a video game before.

The fact so many people dismissed (and [i]continue[/i] to dismiss) this game as just a walking simulator is criminal. Yes, technically it [i]is[/i] a walking sim, but that's [i]really[/i] missing the point. Modern gamers are so hellbent on the notion of "respecting your time" that they are unwilling to take any risks or push their boundaries, then wonder why they get served soulless mediocrity so often. 

Death Stranding is completely unashamed to do its own thing, undeterred by an audience that pretends to know what it wants, and I'm so fucking grateful for it. I can't believe it's taken me this long to play it and the moment the sequel is available on PC I will be dedicating the entire week solely to that. I will forever be thankful to be alive at the same time as Hideo Kojima. Easiest 10/10 I could possibly give. [b]PLAY THIS GAME.[/b]

This game is peak. 

Yes, you walk a lot. Yes, the point of the game is to deliver packages from Point A to Point B. Yes, at times it can get boring. 

But I think that's what makes it what it is. Kojima knew not everyone would enjoy it, but he had a vision and stuck with it. 

Once you envelope yourself in the world of Death Stranding, learn the lore, connect with the characters and experience the environment, you can't stop. 

It's indescribable the "vibe" this game has and in turn you feel, the only way to feel it is to actually play the game. The only way I CAN describe the game is by saying that it's one of those games you'd play when you're super tired from work or school and you just wanna chill. No SBMM lobbies, no sweats, no challenges, no toxicity. It's just you, Norman Reedus, and his Funky Fetus traversing across a world seemingly devoid of any human life. 

At times I'd find myself playing for hours and hours on end. And the truth is that in those sessions I'd mostly be doing side quests or other unimportant stuff that didn't even progress the story. The vibe and relaxation I experienced playing the game just had such a strong grip on me. 

I didn't even mention the story yet. The story is peak storytelling. It had me at tears at times and it got me hooked on anything related to the Death Strandings Universe. It's such an emotion filled story that subtly touches on real world themes and problems that many of us ignore at times. To an extent, the game and it's story can be relatable, therapeutic and alleviating to some. It was certainly a story I personally enjoyed and connected with at times. (I'm not deny however that most of the time you don't know what's going on but that's part of the experience and if you aren't okay, ready or prepared to be confused at times then you might have a negative view towards the story)

I can't wait for whenever they bring Death Stranding 2 to PC, hopefully sometime next year, assuming they will.

There is no reason for your name to be in the credits what feels like 10 times. There is no reason to have 2 full sets of unskippable credits. Navigating the world in the later half of Act 2 is a slog due to the horrible routing and material costs of the highway, forcing you to rely and ziplines that loose there appeal after 1 trip there and back. All of these though, to be honest, dont loose me to the point I wouldn't reccomend a game. What lost me are 2 things, the games story, and the games characters.

He's like Navi in OOT but 10x worse. His job throughout the game is to either 1. tell Sam again what he just learned in the story or 2. to tell Sam to go to a terminal to continue the main story EVERY MAIN ORDER, something what the player is trained to do from the start. It's quite frankly unbeleivable, I hated his character until mid-ending where he actually became a character. The next issue is Fragile. I have quite a stomach for sexualisation in games, as an anime fan I'm pretty decentisised. Lets end this by talking about the story. Death Stranding is, like a lot of games, a simple story told horribly. This lack of ability to tell a story in a consistently engaging way is due to a few things. An inconsistency of major plot beats and an inconsistent tone are a couple, but the major one is as so. It's, in my opinion, the biggest issue of the entire game. This game does not at all respect your time. You go from Point A to Point B, which takes about half an hour, 95% of which is just trying to keep your balance. Sure, the scenery is great, but that doesn't mean I'll be entertained just slogging through it for hours trying not to trip over rocks. As much as Kojima knocks modern games for redundancy and following "safe" design, Death Stranding seems to be an archetype for so many of the open world/AAA tropes we've come to know and loathe, such as drawing things out painfully and a needlessly complicated interface (just to give ONE example, you have to go through the Map just to save. I can see that this game was going for something deep and artistic, and I respect that. All of these though, to be honest, dont loose me to the point I wouldn't reccomend a game. What lost me are 2 things, the games story, and the games characters.

Lets end this by talking about the story. Death Stranding is, like a lot of games, a simple story told horribly. This lack of ability to tell a story in a consistently engaging way is due to a few things. An inconsistency of major plot beats and an inconsistent tone are a couple, but the major one is as so. It's, in my opinion, the biggest issue of the entire game. This game does not at all respect your time. If your playing this game for just the story, your time is so flagrantly and blatantly wasted its very very aggravating. You are forced to watch the FULL credits TWICE, both unskipable, one of those instances mid game, where all you have to do gameplay wise is run around in an empty space with nothing to do. I've been very negative and I think this game deserves it. With what I said in mind, I do want to say though that these issues arent critital for this IP. I can put it into words at the moment but there is a TON of untapped potention in this style of game, its clear after playing this game.

The scenes where top brass are desperately begging Sam to come back, because they desperately need "The Legend," and he wants nothing to do with them because he's the rigid loner who doesn't trust anyone anymore...I felt like I was swimming chin-deep in a vat of 90's/2000's action movie redundancy. I also felt like Sam's personality was a clone of Snake from Metal Gear.

But the big drawback for me was the gameplay. It's basically just fetch quests. That's pretty much it. You go from Point A to Point B, which takes about half an hour, 95% of which is just trying to keep your balance. Sure, the scenery is great, but that doesn't mean I'll be entertained just slogging through it for hours trying not to trip over rocks. As much as Kojima knocks modern games for redundancy and following "safe" design, Death Stranding seems to be an archetype for so many of the open world/AAA tropes we've come to know and loathe, such as drawing things out painfully and a needlessly complicated interface (just to give ONE example, you have to go through the Map just to save. Because you have to access a different System menu than the regular one to save or load, and literally the only difference is the regular one doesn't have Save/Load for some reason. I can see that this game was going for something deep and artistic, and I respect that. But Kojima seems to be falling into the same traps as all other commercial developers, despite his criticism of them. And that saddens me, because I felt like Kojima was my last gasp of hope for commercial gaming. Guess it's retro, indie or nothing these days.
